annotation.TEXT: Since I don't have much to say about this stage, I may as well get this off my shoulder (and effectively anger the entire MM fanbase in the process): I honestly don't care much for Tornado Man's theme. I don't think it's that bad of a song, but it's far from being the best tune in MM9 (for my money, Concrete Man's theme is where it's at).
As its name implies, the EX Armor reduces damage you receive. Much like the Energy Saver, this item isn't necessary to pick up, but it definitely makes things more manageable in the long run.

As mentioned in the description of the last video, I'll be showing the route to the secret item in Star Man's stage. Even if you haven't seen it before, it should still be obvious as to why I didn't go this way during my main route in the last segment.

Centaur Man actually isn't that difficult, although I do an admittedly terrible job of showing it. He has quite a few new attack patterns, along with his projectiles producing spread-shots after hitting the walls. Overall, this is actually a pretty interesting fight...if you're not trying to bum-rush him with Rain Flush, at least.

Tornado Man is kind of an ass now. While his pattern is relatively the same as before (aside from one new attack - spawning clouds that slow you down when you touch them), the main thing that changes this fight is the addition of the tornado platforms. This seriously limits the amount of space you have to maneuver around Tornado Man, especially since they take up a good portion of the room's floor space.

Ballade (who is apparently channeling the personality of Perfect Cell) is a bit different than the last two Mega Man Killers. Ballade has similar damage output, but his fight is much slower in pace - partly due to him being completely invincible while he's in his second form (which can easily become a bit irritating if he decides to abuse it).

Tornado Blow is virtually the same as it was in MM9, except Metools seem to be resistant to it when they have their helmets down. While it's still a fairly strong weapon, I prefer Centaur Flash over it (mainly because it's slightly faster).

This game's version of Centaur Flash feels more like a slightly buffed version of Gravity Hold (enemies killed by it even fly off-screen in a similar manner). Either way, it's still a decently strong screen-clearing weapon, especially if you have the Energy Saver (which gives it 14 total uses).

Your reward for traversing through that spike gauntlet is Rush Marine, of all things. Although it probably goes without saying: Aside from the secret item route in Centaur Man's stage (and some uses in a few of the Wily levels), you won't be seeing much of it in this playthrough.
